docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Ann Althouse's apologia for the so obviously politically crafted shifts in position on abortion by Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mitt Romney is undeserved (''Rudy & Mitt Hem & Haw on Abortion,'' column, Feb. 24). Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Romney have a similar problem, one not to their credit. Running as Republicans in liberal Northeastern areas, both sought to reassure pro-choice voters that they had nothing to fear from their election.
docs.abstract: Three letters comment on Feb 24 Ann Althouse Op-Ed column on positions of Republican presidential hopefuls Rudolph Giuliani and Mitt Romney on abortion; Floyd Abrams says Giuliani and Romney are hedging in order to appeal to people on both sides; Nancy N Northup, president of Center for Reproductive Rights, contends consequences of Roe reversal would be drastic; Richard H Escobales Jr, who identifies himself as pro-life Republican, says positions taken by Giuliani and Romney are muddled

docs.lead_paragraph: Black women have significantly higher rates of premature birth than white women, and a new study suggests there may be underlying genetic factors even when other known risks are taken into account. The researchers, who published their findings this month in The American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology, say that even though preterm birth is not a desirable outcome, it may provide some advantage, perhaps protection against diseases -- in somewhat the same way the gene for sickle cell confers protection against malaria.

headline.main: Study Points to Genetics in Disparities in Preterm Births

docs.abstract: Drs Louis J Muglia and F Sessions Cole, Washington University pediatrics professors, lead study on premature births that suggests genetics may play part in baby being born early; emphasize that while there is likely genetic component, other risk factors, like family history and environment, play part in pre-term birth; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple of people asked me about the numbers in my maternal mortality column and multi-media piece, so let me explain. But the first point to note is that nobody has much idea what the numbers are. For example, the "official" figure in Ethiopia for maternal mortality is roughly 800 deaths for women for every 100,000 live births. But that figure is based on hospital data, and the Fistula Hospital estimates that the real figure is probably more like 2,000 out of every 100,000 live births. In addition, the causes can be multiple: For example, malaria is particularly lethal to pregnant women, so the cause of death may be malaria but it is also a consequence of her pregnancy and should be concidered a case of maternal mortality.

docs.lead_paragraph: Praise for U.S. Attorneys Dismissed by Justice Dept. Internal Justice Department performance reports for six of the eight U.S. attorneys dismissed in recent months rated them ''well regarded'' or ''very competent.'' The evaluations, which were not made public before, raise questions about why the prosecutors were let go. PAGE 19 A Sorority Showdown Twenty-three women were asked to leave Delta Zeta sorority at DePauw University, including every member who was overweight or nonwhite. Others left in protest. PAGE 17 Venezuela a Top Arms Buyer Venezuelan arms spending has exceeded $4 billion in the past two years, putting the nation ahead of major buyers like Pakistan and Iran. Venezuela says the fighter jets, attack helicopters and Kalashnikovs are to counter potential aggression from the United States. PAGE 3 T: Women's Fashion The New York Times Style Magazine details the trends for spring, from a new fascination with the future to graphic prints and ethnic influences. Also: Cathy Horyn goes behind the scenes at Yves Saint Laurent. Review of Judge's Cases In an unusual move, a federal appeals court is recommending that an appeals board review immigration cases involving a New York judge whose asylum hearings have been criticized. PAGE 25 Finance Chief for Citigroup Citigroup is expected to name a top officer of American Express as its new chief financial officer in a move aimed at ending weeks of top management turmoil. PAGE 27 Opinion: Death by Pregnancy Nicholas D. Kristof, from Ethiopia, on what happens when the U.S. cuts aid to women in the developing world. WEEK IN REVIEW, PAGE 15 All Access, No Insight The Carpetbagger looks back on his humbling Oscar season on the edge of celebrity. ARTS & LEISURE
